channel.title: Massive Logging Idea
channel.description:
I recently had an idea of possibly logging every single int, boolean, array, string, and whatnot of the client. It would take some time, don't get me wrong, but it'd be a very neat debugging tool no doubt.
The question is: would it fuck the client's computer over? Well, I tried to debug a 4D-array the other day (the boolean array array array array that handles whether a tile be displayed or not) which took approximately three hours... but I still am up to putting time into logging everything. Unless someone has already done this?

item.title: Massive Logging Idea
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

I’ve tried something similar before, but there’s far too much information presented to make any real sense of it unless you invest an extraordinary amount of time. I spent a day on static integers alone and all I could come up with is the static int that stores weight, a static int that increments if a projectile comes at you, and a few other relatively useless values. Strings might be more useful, but again, it’s just far too much information to sift through especially without any real context. Not only that, but there are many useless method counters, etc that would make it all the more difficult.

EDIT: Presumably, you could attach an omniscient debugger and find values that way, but I haven’t tried that method.

Read full topic

item.title: Massive Logging Idea
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“Zachera, post:5, topic:204192”][quote author=frank_ link=topic=269684.msg2215331#msg2215331 date=1210074581]
what is the point of logging values that change every fraction of a second

and it would only take 3 hours if you were doing it in a very very very bad way, such as opening the file, writing a line, then closing the file and repeating
[/quote]
That’s exactly what I did, heh. What would you suggest then? Get all the values into a massive array and output the array?[/quote]they are already in a massive array

Read full topic

item.title: Massive Logging Idea
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:6, topic:204192”][quote author=BAsh(CntLgn) link=topic=269684.msg2215440#msg2215440 date=1210092830]
Writing the difference is a better idea. Hook calls to that set the array and its elements (that will get a bit more complex - but still possible) and then just write that. Alternatively you could pause all the threads in the client, and create a copy of the array. Then unpause, pause, write the difference, rinse and repeat.
[/quote]
Probably still take just as long though[/quote]
Are you talking about the first or second method?

Read full topic

item.title: Massive Logging Idea
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

BAsh(CntLgn):

Writing the difference is a better idea. Hook calls to that set the array and its elements (that will get a bit more complex - but still possible) and then just write that. Alternatively you could pause all the threads in the client, and create a copy of the array. Then unpause, pause, write the difference, rinse and repeat.

Probably still take just as long though

Read full topic

and it would only take 3 hours if you were doing it in a very very very bad way, such as opening the file, writing a line, then closing the file and repeating[/quote]

item.title: Massive Logging Idea
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

Writing the difference is a better idea. Hook calls to that set the array and its elements (that will get a bit more complex - but still possible) and then just write that. Alternatively you could pause all the threads in the client, and create a copy of the array. Then unpause, pause, write the difference, rinse and repeat.

stream logging is useful.
